Anyone uses rev swerve? Is it ok for me to take a peek on your code?
We are trying to start on swerve in java this year. Any help is welcomed.

edit: Just checked, we are using rev motor neo and ctre encoder

I believe REV provides code templates for you to look at here

If you decide to go with another manufacturer (which I would recommend), either SDS or WCP, there are other options for mostly pre-generated code like YAGSL, and CTRE swerve.

We already brought our swerve drive, and I believe it‚Äôs using rev‚Äôs hardware. Is it possible to switch to CTRE or YAGSL? Or do we have to order new pairs of swerve hardware?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T06:46:08.343Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":618,"readers_count":617,"score":143.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"Alex He","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":59620,"username":"clavin","name":"Calvin Hou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/clavin/{size}/211896_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64323,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"time for an academic..calm down?"},"post_url":"/t/rev-swerve/464465/3","custom_user_title":"time for an academic..calm down?","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373089,"name":"Calvin Hou","username":"clavin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/clavin/{size}/211896_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T06:57:44.345Z","cooked":"

If you have purchased REV swerve already then you will need to either use REV‚Äôs code or YAGSL. The requirement for CTRE swerve is that you are using fully ctre hardware on the module, so motors and encoders.

clavin:

go with another manufacturer (which I would recommend)

Can you expand on this more? We‚Äôve been running MAXSwerve for 2 seasons now, and have absolutely loved them. Just curious what the reasoning is behind that statement?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T12:59:36.989Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":443,"readers_count":442,"score":198.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/rev-swerve/464465/5","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373187,"name":"Jun","username":"Junhee","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/junhee/{size}/222415_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T13:00:46.475Z","cooked":"

It is possible to use YAGSL with REV hardware with no changes to the hardware that you already have.

A team that I worked with this season had great success getting their modules to work, switching from REV template code to YAGSL, just by copy and pasting large segments of code from the example code that YAGSL provides.

There were no hardware changes required; and I found it quite easy (even with no programming background) to help implement YAGSL.

The example code is already provided in the documentation, but I‚Äôll link it below in case it makes it any easier to access.

github.com

GitHub - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example: Yet Another General Swerve Library Example...

main

Yet Another General Swerve Library Example Project - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T13:01:03.933Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":405,"readers_count":404,"score":175.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"Jun","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example/tree/main","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example: Yet Another General Swerve Library Example Project","clicks":51}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30509,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"NYC Volunteer / (Semi?) Professional Yapper"},"post_url":"/t/rev-swerve/464465/6","custom_user_title":"NYC Volunteer / (Semi?) Professional Yapper","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373202,"name":"Jun","username":"Junhee","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/junhee/{size}/222415_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T13:14:00.847Z","cooked":"

A couple of issues I‚Äôve seen teams have with the MAXSwerve modules (mostly user mistakes, so I don‚Äôt believe you should be rushing to switch unless someone has other examples of a MAXSwerve issue solely related to the module):

  1. The bolts on the wheels tend to loosen over use, and it is easy to forget to use threadlocker, leading to the bolts coming loose. If you‚Äôre lucky, they just fall out onto the field during use, but the worst case scenario is the bolt coming out and getting jammed inside of the forks (I believe that‚Äôs what they‚Äôre called), which locks the wheel from moving. If this happens, the wheel tends to wear out to an extreme point over the course of just one match.

  2. Same issue as the above, but for the bolts on the gearboxes. I‚Äôve seen the small 25mm M3 bolts come loose over time and fall into the gears of the module, which tends to bend them in a 90 degree angle. I don‚Äôt think this affected the module‚Äôs ability to spin, but it does require spares of the 25mm bolts, which I do not believe the modules come with.

  3. There was another larger bolt, positioned in-axis with the encoder, which also tends to come loose. When taken to the extreme, it starts to press on the encoder and I believe was the cause of the failure of the encoder in the module for one of the teams I worked with, which we spent over an hour trying to debug and replace. In a competition setting, this is a lot of time that is no bueno.

Generally, threadlocker works wonders, and although I believe the instructions do say to use it, it is really easy to forget until you learn the hard way the first time, and generally at that point you have to disassemble all your modules to apply the threadlocker.

  1. I‚Äôve also found that the adaptors for the encoder ‚Üí SparkMAXes tend to be very loose. Hot glue is your friend, but this is still another potential failure point.

This also does not take into account the fact that the REV software library had a lot of issues when working with the new Vortex motors in the beginning of the season (encroaching into week 2 of competitions I believe), but that only affected some teams working with the MAXSwerve, as I do not believe the issues affected NEO motors.

The wheels also seem to wear out rather quickly, but I am wondering if that may be an issue with improper alignment of the modules.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T13:18:45.237Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":27,"reads":352,"readers_count":351,"score":255.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"Jun","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19532,"username":"cad321","name":"Brian Wagg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30509,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"NYC Volunteer / (Semi?) Professional Yapper","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373207,"name":"","username":"ConnorMasini","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/ac8455/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T13:21:50.032Z","cooked":"

This is our repository built off of REV‚Äôs MaxSwerve codebase. We started with the max swerve codebase and added some upgrades to give us fine tuned movement with the DPAD and auto-orientation using right trigger + ABXY. All of this code is in the MoveCommand.java file in this repo: GitHub - cjmasini/mechanical-pumas-2024: Repository for Team 6616 FRC 2024 code . Let me know if you have any questions. We used MaxSwerve this year and had a good experience with it.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T13:21:50.032Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":301,"readers_count":300,"score":120.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/cjmasini/mechanical-pumas-2024","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - cjmasini/mechanical-pumas-2024: Repository for Team 6616 FRC 2024 code","clicks":41}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65822,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6616 Coach"},"post_url":"/t/rev-swerve/464465/8","custom_user_title":"6616 Coach","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373211,"name":"Sam Knight","username":"knightscape","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knightscape/{size}/137599_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T13:27:14.491Z","cooked":"

We used MAXSwerve through this season for the first time. We experienced the effects of 1, 2, and 3 at our first event week 1. All of which were remedied with blue loctite. The documentation wasn‚Äôt super clear on where to loctite, we then opted to loctite everything. We ran through our second competition and NEDCMPs with no issues. Even when we experienced loose bolts it was all easily and quickly fixable in the moment. The wheels we swapped out to Thrifty‚Äôs aluminum wheels with neoprene treads before NEDCMP and had no issues with treadwear during the event. All in all we loved the kit and found it easy to work with. We are planning on investing in a second set. We started out at ‚Äúmid‚Äù speed gearing before opting for ‚Äúhigh‚Äù when powered by regular NEOs.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T13:27:14.491Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":286,"readers_count":285,"score":102.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"Sam Knight","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":30509,"username":"Junhee","name":"Jun","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/junhee/{size}/222415_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44427,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4473 - Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/rev-swerve/464465/9","custom_user_title":"4473 - Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373221,"name":"Liu","username":"Liu346","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/liu346/{size}/125023_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T13:39:16.333Z","cooked":"

Also make sure to properly lubricate with white lithium. Some gears on Rev swerve are aluminum which isnt necessarily bad, but it does make them much more likely to wear vs steel gears. I would highly recommend running them like crazy as soon as you can, you will learn about all the small tips and tricks just by taking it apart and putting it back together 100 times.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T14:11:16.738Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":254,"readers_count":253,"score":105.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"Liu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27749,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9072 - Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/rev-swerve/464465/10","custom_user_title":"9072 - Drive Coach","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373239,"name":"","username":"TyJac42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyjac42/{size}/230279_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T14:00:11.055Z","cooked":"

All the drive gears are all steel according to rev‚Äôs website. The azimuth gear might be aluminum, but the load on that gear is significantly less than the load for driving. Lubrication is always still important though.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T14:00:11.055Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":227,"readers_count":226,"score":95.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":27749,"username":"Liu346","name":"Liu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/liu346/{size}/125023_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53544,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming, CAD"},"post_url":"/t/rev-swerve/464465/11","custom_user_title":"Programming, CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373257,"name":"Jsteel","username":"Jsteel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/9de053/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T14:22:37.130Z","cooked":"

To the OP: please do not doubt your choice of the Rev swerve units. We used them this season with a lot of success. Any unit you buy will have a startup curve. Ours was very small with the Rev units.

I would suggest starting with the Rev swerve library for programming. That is what we did. We had actually bought another swerve module from another supplier, and our programmers struggled with it. The Rev units they had running within a day.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-04-25T14:22:37.130Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":85.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464465,"topic_slug":"rev-swerve","display_username":"Jsteel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24050,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/rev-swerve/464465/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3373275,"name":"Matt Pizzimenti","username":"mjpizz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjpizz/{size}/186680_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T14:39:26.405Z","cooked":"

Churrobots have been running on Rev MaxSwerve successfully for 2 years now, and they‚Äôve worked great for us! We didn‚Äôt try other modules so I can‚Äôt give a comparison. Software-wise, we have made only minor modifications (mostly tuning and PathPlanner integration) to the template code from Rev:

github.com

churrobots/2024-crescendo/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Drivetrain.java

// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.
//
package frc.robot.subsystems;

import com.ctre.phoenix.sensors.WPI_Pigeon2;
import com.pathplanner.lib.auto.AutoBuilder;
import com.pathplanner.lib.util.HolonomicPathFollowerConfig;
import com.pathplanner.lib.util.PIDConstants;
import com.pathplanner.lib.util.ReplanningConfig;

import edu.wpi.first.math.filter.SlewRateLimiter;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Pose2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Rotation2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Translation2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.ChassisSpeeds;
import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.SwerveDriveKinematics;
import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.SwerveDriveOdometry;
import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.SwerveModulePosition;
This file has been truncated. show original

A few things to be aware of though:

  1. Superglue the keys in the drive shafts on the Neo. Otherwise the key could fall out and lock up the module. For some reason we couldn‚Äôt find this recommendation in the documentation, but it was discussed a bunch on CD last year so it‚Äôs institutional knowledge for us now
  2. Be careful not to over-tighten the MaxPlanetary gearbox ‚Äústack‚Äù. It will compress and damage the gearbox, and make your 550 turning motor burn out trying to turn it.
  3. Watch the status lights on the SparkMax controllers if you‚Äôre getting weird behavior. We found that we had a partially-shorted 550, which only triggered the orange/magenta error status lights at specific angles (as we hand-turned it)
  4. And ditto to blue loctite!! Rev provides a helpful documentation video for where you should apply it.

After you get those basics set up, and you want to get more mileage:

  1. ThriftyBot aluminum wheels and tread were GREAT for us at Worlds. We preferred these much more than the standard plastic wheels, since the wheel diameter stays much more consistent ‚Äî the tread doesn‚Äôt wear down as quickly or as much as the plastic wheels. We also had significantly more traction, so it allowed us to speed up our autos without too much wheel slipping. Plus it just drove better. The only downside is that the fork must be removed when you are performing a wheel swap.
  2. Purchase the gear upgrade kit if you want more speed. You can get an extra high gear version that should put you at 20ft/s (the standard kit maxes out at 15ft/s)

Hope that helps!

Hello. 997 Mentor here (I work with Yuxuan) and wanted to clarify a few things:
1 - We are using SDS Mk4i swerve modules
2 - All motors/controllers are NEO/SparkMax
3 - Absolute encoder is the CANandcoder (helium encoder) connected directly to the Turning Motor‚Äôs SparkMax.
4, NavX gyro connected through the SPI bus on the NXP connector.

We KNOW this configuration does work (in python) however we REALLY want to convert it to WPILIB java. Too bad CoPilot and other LLMs can‚Äôt convert the code reasonably :-).

We also know that the hardware is working (as witnessed by the functional python code). We can ready the absolute angle from the helium encoder with the correct orientation (CCW positive) and know the inversions for all of the motors and gyro.

Thank you for all of the great ideas. We will review them and see what works best.

Enjoy!

Sounds good, in your case i would heavily recommend looking into YAGSL. It has support for all your hardware and the config should be pretty easy and straight forward. YAGSL has great documentation, and the developer is very active on chief delphi and on the unofficial FRC discord.

I‚Äôm a 157 Mentor, and we have been using REV for Swerve for the past 2 years. We have been using SDS mk4 (not inverted), cancoders, Neos (and this year, vortexes for our drive motors) on spark maxes, and the NavX via the MXP connector. Last year we did a custom implementation, and this year we switched to YAGSL. We had a bit of difficulty getting it to work, and pathplanner is still having issues so we might be doing some stuff wrong, but for teleop it works great. Feel free to look at either codebase on our GitHub if you think it would help!

GitHub

Aztechs FRC Team 157

Assabet Valley High School FIRST Robotics. Aztechs FRC Team 157 has 48 repositories available. Follow their code on GitHub.

Edit: added more details on our setup

mjpizz:

The only downside is that the fork must be removed when you are performing a wheel swap.

I like where teams just filed these down to fit without removing a fork. That was clever.

We ended up using the 111 TPU wheels last two competitions. And only changed a couple times each. I may try the recommended TPU MatterHacker Pro rather than Inland but we didn‚Äôt have any big issues for a lighter robot (99 lb).

We were on second full year with modules without any big issues. Switching to vortex for drive on high pinion. We changed the period and depth for the encoder in code, added feedforward for each module and tuned that, slightly decreased the slew limiting, raised the current limits to 80a, and then added PathPlanner and photonvision code for this year. Logging and viewing in advantagescope helped a lot with this.

All great advice on loctite and not over tightening (check motors turn freely while tightening). We also modified the wheel alignment tool to fit over the printed tires, and make sure they are well aligned, we had a little unexpected turning at one point when one was 6 degrees off.

I had some issues with pathplanner due to the velocities of modules and the swerve drive mainly, you have to set the max robot velocity really low and a realistic max module velocity to ensure that your PathPlanner PIDs work. It‚Äôs all apart of the learning experience.

You didn‚Äôt make the mistake of writing your robot relative drive method to take chassis speed but then calling the drive method (that takes 0-1 joystick inputs)? We did that and so all the PathPlanner commands were multiplied twice by the max speed leading to really bad path following unless it was slow.

After fixing that the paths were much better and I had the max speed in both the code and PathPlanner for the modules to be around 5.76 m/s. Though we set ~4 m/s for default.

I did see worse odometry above the max speed, but tested up to 11 m/s^2 acceleration (double our max) to see how fast the robot would go, which was ~1.6 seconds from subwoofer to centerline (and bunching up carpet at home when it stopped).
